story:
Most of us know people who've been affected by cancer, and I am no different - as I get older, it's a sobering thought that more and more people I know have been directly impacted.

I love the work of Macmillan, and during the next 4 weeks, i wanted to do something that would help them and challenge me mentally and physically.

So...I came up with the idea of running 100 miles between 5th November and 2nd December...that's 3.57 miles per day on average.

But to add a special slant to it...I'm only looking for a donation of 2p per mile - so nothing more than £2 - in fact I don't want individual donations of more than that! I wanted to make it wider reaching and see if i could get 125 people to support this and i thought it would be easier to do this if the donation amount was lower!

My employers will match whatever I raise up to £250, so let's make it £500 for Macmillan and help them to continue their awe inspiring work!

story:
Thanks for taking the time to visit my JustGiving page.

Lisa Graffin was originally diagnosed with breast cancer in 2014. She underwent chemotherapy and radiotherapy and was given the all clear in April 2015. 

Unfortunately Lisa found out in December 2019 that the cancer had returned in her spine,, breast bone and lymph nodes and she underwent further radiotherapy and chemotherapy and after an initial good response Lisa was placed in remission in March 2020.

Lisa found out the cancer had returned in July 2020 and yet again Lisa went under another course of chemotherapy.

The cancer in her breast bone and lymph nodes continued to shrink however early October we were given the devastating news that it had spread to the lining of her brain and her spinal column. The cancer was so aggressive that there wasn’t time for Lisa to receive any treatment before she sadly she lost her battle on the 29th October 2020. 

Throughout Lisa’s treatment she always remained positive, never once complained and always put others before her own needs! 

Lisa was a kind, brave, courageous woman and the world is a much smaller and darker place without her. 

Lisa leaves behind her husband Shaun, her two daughters Sophie & Jenna, her granddaughter Bella, her mother Betty, and her brother Clive as well as other family members and many close friends. She will truly be sorely missed by everyone who got the pleasure of ever meeting her.

This money will be donated to Macmillan in honour of Lisa Graffin, all other cancer patients and surviving families.

story:
On the 26th October 2020 we lost our Captain Peter Leighton to cancer after a short and tough 3 month battle.

Peter was nothing short of a brilliant. He was one of those people that "could turn his hand to anything". A successful businessman. A natural footballer, cricketer and an even better tennis player. Though his true brilliance and love was as a lecturer and teacher.

It was a rare occasion when you could go out with Peter and not be approached by one of his students wanting to thank him and wish him well.

Peter was a true believer in education. It was aright of passage for each grand child to get "extra" GCSE maths tutoring aged 15 and 16 much to the amusements of the older/previous relatives.  

During Peter's illness Macmillan provided support and guidance to Peter and family. Constant companions during very difficult and challenging times. Peter's family would like to say thank you.

Please give what you can so that they can continue to help many other families when it gets very very, tough... God knows they will need them.

Thank you....

story:
I'm doing this challenge for several reasons, all very close to my heart.

As some may know, I was diagnosed with stage 1 tongue cancer in February 2020, which turned my world upside down.  I was just 35. 
Everything happened so fast and 10 days later I underwent 2 major head and neck surgeries. Thankfully surgery alone was enough to cure me, but I want to raise as much awareness of this awful disease as possible.

I know its hard right now, but please have regular check ups with your dentist. If you notice any changes in your mouth or on your tongue, please get yourself checked out. 

Mine started with a sore tongue when eating spicy food. That's it. I could of easily ignored this. My dentist did the first time I went too. So trust your gut and go back if things don't get better. I'm so glad I did. 

I'm doing this challenge to give something back. Macmillan have helped me massively this year and still continue to support me if and when I need it. 
 
I'm also doing this challenge to give me something to focus on during lockdown 2. I need the focus and I find it helps me massively mentally if I turn the negatives into positives. 

Thank you so much for reading, if you can id be so grateful for a donation, if you cant donate no problem, but please remember my story and share it to raise awareness. Thank you

story: Thanks for visiting my page. I'm raising money for the British Heart Foundation and I'd be so grateful for your support. The BHF has helped halve the number of people dying from heart and circulatory disease in the UK but sadly every day hundreds of people lose their lives. It's only thanks to support from people like us that the BHF can create new treatments and discover new cures. £24 could pay for two hours of research by an early career scientist, but every pound helps so please give what you can to help me hit my target. Thanks!

story:
The 12 Guide Dogs of Christmas Collection 

Help us as we aim to raise enough to support 12 brand new guide dogs 
this Christmas! 

During December the four-legged volunteers of the Salisbury Group would usually be out and about wagging their tails and meeting you at collections and events in your community.  

Due to the current situation, we’re not able to be out as much this 
festive season, and we know you will miss seeing our life-changing doggy volunteers! We’re hoping you will help us and donate to our ‘12 Guide Dogs of Christmas’ Collection as we aim to raise enough for 12 new guide dog partnerships!  

It costs over £56,000 to fund the lifetime cost of a guide dog. Please consider donating £12 during our 12-day collection so we can fund 12 new life-changers this Christmas.  

We appreciate that times are difficult, but for people with sight loss, 
social isolation can be their everyday. You can help them feel less alone, now and in the future. 

Don’t forget to send it on through Facebook, WhatsApp, email or text and get your friends and family involved too. 

Thank you and Merry Christmas

The 12 Guide Dogs of Christmas Collection

Help us as we aim to raise enough to support 12 brand new guide dogs
this Christmas!

During December the four-legged volunteers of the South Wirral fundraising group would usually be out and about wagging their tails and meeting you at collections and events in your community.

Due to the current situation, we’re not able to be out as much this
festive season, and we know you will miss seeing our life-changing doggy volunteers! We’re hoping you will help us and donate to our ‘12 Guide Dogs of Christmas’ Collection as we aim to raise enough for 12 new guide dog partnerships!

It costs over £56,000 to fund the lifetime cost of a guide dog. Please consider donating £12 during our 12-day collection so we can fund 12 new life-changers this Christmas.

We appreciate that times are difficult, but for people with sight loss,
social isolation can be their everyday. You can help them feel less alone, now and in the future.

Don’t forget to send it on through Facebook, WhatsApp, email or text and get your friends and family involved too.

Thank you and Merry Christmas!

story:
The 12 Guide Dogs of Christmas Collection
Help us as we aim to raise enough to support 12 brand new guide dogs
this Christmas!
During December the four-legged volunteers of the Heswall fundraising group would usually be out and about wagging their tails and meeting you at collections and events in your community.
Due to the current situation, we’re not able to be out as much this
festive season, and we know you will miss seeing our life-changing doggy volunteers! We’re hoping you will help us and donate to our ‘12 Guide Dogs of Christmas’ Collection as we aim to raise enough for 12 new guide dog partnerships!
It costs over £56,000 to fund the lifetime cost of a guide dog. Please consider donating £12 during our 12-day collection so we can fund 12 new life-changers this Christmas.
We appreciate that times are difficult, but for people with sight loss,
social isolation can be their everyday. You can help them feel less alone, now and in the future.
Don’t forget to send it on through Facebook, WhatsApp, email or text and get your friends and family involved too.
Thank you and Merry Christmas!

A world with enough support to make the challenges of sight loss no barrier to fulfilling hopes and dreams.

story:
We find ourselves on the brink of a second lockdown and all the restrictions that comes with that on the liberties we enjoy from day to day.

The last lockdown for me was one of laxity, lounging and lots of drinking almost every day, I’m quite ashamed to say that I achieved nothing in the prolonged period of time I had away from my normal responsibilities. I followed so many amazing stories of people on social media doing great things for charity and for themselves. So this time round, I’m determined not to make that same mistake again and repeat my habits of the previous lockdown. I also sadly lost my Grandma & Grandad through the course of this pandemic to cancer so it made absolute sense to choose Cancer Research UK as my cause.

With that in mind, I’ve decided to do something that is a bit of a trifecta of good in the fact that it is being done for a good charitable cause, is going to be hugely beneficial for me personally/physically/mentally & is also going to be a bit of a challenge.

I’m going to attempt to walk 1 million steps in 30 days starting on the first day of lockdown, Thursday 5th of November. I already walk a lot more than the average person daily, and this feat is going to be almost tripling what I do on an average day. The magic number is 33,334 steps per day to take me over that 1 million landmark. Or around 16.5 miles per day for someone of my height and stride length.

The key to doing this is going to be keeping a healthy calorific diet as I’ll be burning around 5,000 calories a day, sleeping well and not drinking. So, regrettably, my next pint isn’t going to be until December 4th and will be a celebratory one hopefully.

My trusty Golden Retriever, Luna, will be accompanying me mostly along the way and I’ll be documenting everything on my FitBit tracker & Strava and will be giving regular visual updates on my Instagram page: KallyTM.

Please donate whatever you feel is acceptable, here’s to the next 30 days.

charity.registrationNumber: 207994 (England & Wales) and SC038731 (Scotland)
story:
We're here to support people with serious illnesses in the Newcastle area to have the best quality of life possible, whatever that might mean for them.

Our hospice team includes doctors, nurses, physiotherapists, social workers and many more, and is supported by over 100 volunteers, who play a vital role in the running of the hospice. 

Some people stay in our 20-bed in-patient unit, where relatives and friends can visit any time of the day or night, and stay with their loved ones if they wish.

Our day therapy unit offers outpatient clinics and a wide range of activities and therapies, including baking, art therapy and relaxation. 

We also provide support for carers and families, including our social work team who provide emotional and practical advice. Our chaplain is here to provide spiritual care to patients and their loved ones.

Thank you for supporting us, and helping to make sure more people with a terminal illness in the Newcastle area get the care and support they need.
